title: IBM VR Language-Learning Tool
summary: Built a realistic VR environment with world-space vocabulary panels, glow-on-hover cues, and push-to-talk interactions to support language learning.
highlights: Configurable XR player with interactables and physics tuning
Diegetic overlays, day-night ambience, production-ready asset sourcing

problem: Learners needed an immersive practice space that could scale scenarios without overwhelming newcomers to VR.
Stakeholders required a prototype aligned with IBM accessibility guidelines.
approach: Mapped the learning journey to VR micro-interactions, layering world-space prompts, haptics, and glow affordances.
Authored variation-ready scene prefabs with lighting cycles, spatial audio beds, and optimised baked textures.
outcome: Reduced cognitive load during vocabulary drills by surfacing context-aware highlights.
Established a reusable interaction blueprint for IBM's wider XR education initiatives.

title: Smoothie Operator (Distinction)
summary: Two-player fruit-slicing PC game; led sprints and engineering to deliver a polished gameplay loop.
highlights: Designed memory-recipe mechanics with responsive keyboard play
Delivered sprint ceremonies and polish pass to secure Distinction

problem: Team needed a fast-moving party game concept that balanced cooperation and competition.
Prototype required clear UX flows so new players could onboard in under a minute.
approach: Facilitated sprint rituals and backlog grooming to keep scope aligned with three-week milestones.
Implemented input handling, visual feedback, and scoring HUD using vanilla JavaScript.
outcome: Earned Distinction grade for the module and positive heuristics feedback from playtesters.
Provided reusable architecture for future browser-based multiplayer experiments.
